FC963C76CACF4CE2AC48372C593EA95C.description: Design and conduct a probability experiment in which one outcome is more likely to occur than the other outcome.

0FDCD2CDF2CD4640B3BDA61BA77D1044.description: Design and conduct a probability experiment in which one outcome is equally likely to occur as the other outcome.

7615FC288EA24D1F8BB807417472760C.description: Design and conduct a probability experiment in which one outcome is less likely to occur than the other outcome.

AFC3B3C6BAE54D928B82D578D336F2FB.description: Identify outcomes from a given probability experiment that are less likely, equally likely, or more likely to occur than other outcomes.

8B45F5A77F5349FDAA1EDA40BDD3CC0E.description:
Students will be expected to compare the likelihood of two possible outcomes occurring, using
words such as less likely, equally likely, or more likely.

C9084D4BCD6347789D9F24A24C0D60C1.description: Conduct a given probability experiment a number of times, record the outcomes, and explain the results.

0B6FD225EE944BE4BF504495E1E1C041.description: Design and conduct a probability experiment in which the likelihood of a single outcome occurring is impossible, possible, or certain.

83405671D2114985A2665DE033D4EC93.description: Classify the likelihood of a single outcome occurring in a probability experiment as impossible, possible, or certain.

B35013FF2A6646BC8EDF88D5C68055F2.description: Identify examples of events from personal contexts that are impossible, possible, or certain.

75B8AF6575634051B218EBFE0B062954.description:
Students will be expected to describe the likelihood of a single outcome occurring, using words
such as impossible, possible, and certain.

BE47A5DA63F5485FAAD0204A9BA11C0A.description: Solve a given problem by constructing and interpreting a double bar graph.

FCAA3341620C4D45ADEC9892281C3275.description: Identify examples of double bar graphs used in a variety of print and electronic media, such as newspapers, magazines, and the Internet.

037A513E89D248B0AE47DF06C743F84D.description: Draw conclusions from a given double bar graph to answer questions.

CF2EBCAEB03B4205B56EC52A91B2211C.description: Represent a given set of data by creating a double bar graph, label the title and axes, and create a legend without the use of technology.

1CDF801C3E904DF6A5072DD3AD5D4AB7.description: Determine the attributes (title, axes, intervals, and legend) of double bar graphs by comparing a given set of double bar graphs.

8A58531106B14531A3EB2E2545CE8184.description: Students will be expected to construct and interpret double bar graphs to draw conclusions.

DD65530905A64A5981037AF4FA211F5D.description: Find examples of second-hand data in print and electronic media, such as newspapers, magazines, and the Internet.

8E4B843881564F039A4BC00CA69794E3.description: Formulate a question that can best be answered using second-hand data and explain why.

7F232F31B0ED4A2493EF5B781C134AB0.description: Formulate a question that can best be answered using first-hand data and explain why.

387A87041F9F4049BF9247F8698328E3.description: Explain the difference between first-hand and second-hand data.

71668EE0FDE146AA8C969AC372B2A9F8.description: Students will be expected to construct and interpret double bar graphs to draw conclusions.

458A7300BB4C46EB91D376912995B6C3.description: Identify angles greater than or less than a right angle.

1199AF84FFD64BAE82036B3B923C9AFD.description: Label a right angle, using a symbol.

490A1C993E8D4888AC96C3CF756995ED.description: Sketch right angles without the use of a protractor.

5C76F6FBD2BE431298040B721F3E0718.description: Provide examples of right angles in the environment.

DBC410312C2F42AF8D295D57864D0018.description: Students will be expected to identify right angles.

C474C9BF56EA413099A2849C4869FA84.description: Predict the result of a single transformation of a 2-D shape and verify the prediction.

51D72226A410494F84390B0BFBDD2340.description: Draw a 2-D shape, reflect the shape, and identify the line of reflection and the distance of the image from the line of reflection.

1FF278B0397E47678E40BC86E0C9F664.description: Draw a 2-D shape, rotate the shape about a vertex, and describe the direction of the turn (clockwise or counter-clockwise) and the fraction of the turn (limited to 1 4 , 1 2 , 3 4 , or full turn).

1218FE7B2A9A426AB584393143E5E8BC.description: Draw a 2-D shape, translate the shape, and record the translation by describing the direction and magnitude of the movement.

4918B0CFA894424AAA87001BE0C94DEB.description: Perform a transformation of a given 2-D shape by following instructions.

E34F7ED4652348A1818C56EF4020659A.description: Reflect a given 2-D shape in a line of reflection, draw the image, and describe the position and orientation of the image.

0448A1BDF8784D4597F312F8D9DD3883.description: Rotate a given 2-D shape about a vertex, draw the image, and describe the position and orientation of the image.

36D32D6CB5B8438F98868D090915ACC7.description: Translate a given 2-D shape horizontally, vertically, or diagonally, draw the image, and describe the position and orientation of the image.

4E93B50870C444DFBF78FDD1F22CC4B1.description:
Students will be expected to perform a single transformation (translation, rotation, or reflection) of
a 2-D shape (with and without technology) and draw and describe the image.

BC507EFCD54645879C4CB2D38E1302AA.description: Describe the sides of a given 2-D shape using terms such as parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, or horizontal.

01132B5AA8E242198616E255BE918864.description: Describe the faces and edges of a given 3-D object using terms such as parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, or horizontal.

971F2788E3BA4A6B92BF9A40A01DCF0F.description: Build 3-D objects that have edges and faces that are parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, or horizontal.

597D12EE8909432A913CD3FF0DF202D5.description: Draw 2-D shapes that have sides that are parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, or horizontal.

DEB6880C0ECC485DB3E8548C9FADF26B.description: Find examples of edges, faces, and sides that are parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, and horizontal in print and electronic media, such as newspapers, magazines, and the Internet.

6664B47AC8054FE2B9EC7F37DAEAF778.description: Provide examples from the environment that show parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, and horizontal line segments.

EF8DAE9B4C634C21B9264939E2CD7674.description: Identify parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, and horizontal sides on 2-D shapes.

9722EE66E3EF4F9D81DBE17421718E1B.description: Identify parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, and horizontal edges and faces on 3-D objects.

712F1445212340239C701A56496158D7.description:
Students will be expected to describe and provide examples of edges and faces of 3-D objects,
and sides of 2-D shapes that are parallel, intersecting, perpendicular, vertical, and horizontal.

08BBA117509A46A29336E7D2F7D78341.description: Determine the capacity of a given container using materials that take the shape of the inside of the container (e.g., a liquid, rice, sand, beads), and explain the strategy.

6D0F7EBE70954F2EACEF9A72DC1D18D8.description: Estimate the capacity of a given container using personal referents.

DCBD51E9011C4A7AB1F539051D7AF8A8.description: Determine the capacity unit of a given referent.

8938C6C7A0CD40FFA3FEAED642436F60.description: Provide a referent for one millilitre, and explain the choice.

A6641AB09EA6492BA2CCF4E9E520EF7D.description: Provide a referent for one litre, and explain the choice.

85CF052C883E4FEF891F3861CEA9076B.description: Demonstrate that 1000 millilitres is equivalent to one litre by filling a one-litre container using a combination of smaller containers.

E009992DAFE04500BE5A3E163516DB93.description: measuring and recording capacity (mL or L)

F6040C7039854BC78D31C7433E0D33B3.description: estimating capacity using referents for millilitre (mL) and litre (L)

47FCA16C84FC47A19C61F9BA79A04939.description: selecting and justifying referents for millilitre (mL) and litre (L) units

A166ED56451949ABA38F910974262198.description: describing the relationship between millilitre (mL) and litre (L) units

49603E10AA6D46F9AFC82CCC1D1D24B6.description: Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of capacity by

A2E2B38E5C674403A8329465329FBCCA.description: Construct more than one rectangular prism for a given volume.

7695FB167FD0426CAB234643A3FA618B.description: Construct a rectangular prism for a given volume.

DC84E1E07E684EDA9A73089FE8C49385.description: Determine the volume of a given 3-D object using manipulatives, and explain the strategy.

686C779D170D41F8B68DF1735757E37B.description: Estimate the volume of a given 3-D object using personal referents.

1543F1E107084BA2A8A0C81DBEFA1B81.description: Determine which standard cubic unit is represented by a given referent.

9D37F93317E4468E9CE7CDFB01225D06.description: Provide a referent for a cubic metre, and explain the choice.

6DD02D6A578341A497BC8B3CD830AE49.description: Provide a referent for a cubic centimetre, and explain the choice.

0CBD7375EBCF4B5080F26949310061C0.description: Identify and explain why the cube is the most efficient unit for measuring volume.

AE6D47F7FE2741B4ABCD9BD3CF61037E.description: constructing rectangular prisms for a given volume

EE66BFA882DC473EB14A503E00B6D19E.description: measuring and recording volume (cm3 or m3)

6D9E0C4B116B4346A1A2408D8752AEAE.description: estimating volume using referents for cubic centimetre (cm3) or cubic metre (m3)

8B3F355654E245E29F0730EF16201D84.description: selecting and justifying referents for cubic centimetre (cm3) or cubic metre (m3) units

CBBA585A80D04381A6FDE2B07DD267A0.description: Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of volume by

14A52A14F89F4509805F72A6AC98D7AF.description: Estimate and measure length in millimetres, centimetres, and metres.

C18F11A84BB24B1BB49807BF1998287C.description: Provide examples of instances where millimetres are used as the unit of measure.

8C326F563E3344C085694FD1797E2226.description: Show that 1000 millimetres is equivalent to one metre, using concrete materials.

546C3E4FAEF24BF2B36575401756AAC2.description: Show that 10 millimetres is equivalent to one centimetre, using concrete materials.

2D7BA9BB12454885A3850876FAA66AE7.description: Provide a referent for one metre, and explain the choice.

1DA21488D01B438A894AC32C3B073002.description: Provide a referent for one centimetre, and explain the choice.

D63DCB8AC385409694834C969CF53373.description: Provide a referent for one millimetre, and explain the choice.

2870A98BF61E4DE8ABBCAE6D6E1812D8.description: modelling and describing the relationship between millimetre (mm) and centimetre (cm) units, and between millimetre (mm) and metre (m) units

D76A8A7FA2AC41ABAFA5373F3B560578.description: selecting and justifying referents for the unit millimetre (mm)

AA61EEC2C3654D52BC953AAA1054914B.description: Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of measuring length (mm) by

2A7B04C8DF524CFD8D0C0A4E33D2D113.description: Provide a real-life context for when it is important to consider the relationship between area and perimeter.

7E4CD5ED1DCA4CE3B70B2B1DF9D46588.description: Determine the shape that will result in the least area for any given perimeter.

D34E1B87746E4C72A838BD9ADC3AB838.description: Determine the shape that will result in the greatest area for any given perimeter.

DAFED7E96C0347D89EBFA62C758E1941.description: Draw two or more rectangles for a given area in a problem-solving context.

4EE4980D0A9C47938E682DE798E1ABE8.description: Draw two or more rectangles for a given perimeter in a problem-solving context.

D26E49B9ACAB48D8ABA0E91A4014D7E2.description:
Students will be expected to design and construct different rectangles, given a perimeter or an
area or both (whole numbers), and make generalizations.

5D5192D64531499F9DA6687E73C85641.description: Identify the unknown in a problem; represent the problem with an equation; and solve the problem concretely, pictorially, or symbolically.

4160BB97D1704C30AFB044162C2E7F0F.description: Solve a given single-variable equation with the unknown in any of the terms (e.g., n + 2 = 5, 4 + a = 7, 6 = r – 2, 10 = 2c, 15 ÷ r = 3).

C8F4F1EE8DF140A8B5F0C3861B2182CD.description: Create a problem for a given equation with one unknown.

48F8D9298F5945BABD12195F01A446E7.description: Express a given problem as an equation where the unknown is represented by a letter variable.

7496D61743624E5EA2A387AF0AA8075C.description: Express a given pictorial or concrete representation of an equation in symbolic form.

545F07E100214BC2AA54C0DDF95AD7BF.description: Explain the purpose of the letter variable in a given addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division equation with one unknown (e.g., 36 ÷ n = 6).

22E577C20DDF434484EA04C2EA8944C8.description:
Students will be expected to solve problems involving single-variable, one-step equations with
whole number coefficients and whole number solutions.

81BFF85FFBCC4A828B831392CB5292BA.description: Represent a given pattern visually to verify predictions.

E55DBCAA3E404184BAA7386A7852B50D.description: Solve a given problem by using a pattern rule to determine subsequent terms.

AE6CA572F0E6496797B164DB63F6DF25.description: Predict subsequent terms in a given pattern.

634A4B57B6CB46498871891F75CAB20F.description: Determine and explain why a given number is or is not the next term in a pattern.

F7A6D55B096D48399D5F4B2343B83CA8.description: Describe the relationship in a given table or chart using a mathematical expression.

28B524E06F7A426C97E244BDE3307FBF.description: Write a mathematical expression to represent a given pattern, such as r + 1, r – 1, r + 5.

48E60FD35D0945308240AFB662993D5D.description: Describe, orally or in written form, a given pattern using mathematical language such as one more, one less, or five more.

8855EC9CA80C493CBC97FB3BB1DAC8EB.description: Extend a given increasing or decreasing pattern, with and without concrete materials, and explain how each term differs from the preceding one.

F5CF638296A845CFAA4AA22566E52382.description:
Students will be expected to determine the pattern rule to make predictions about subsequent
terms.

1A265585BB45494BB10EF407F8301A0A.description: Solve problems that involve addition and subtraction of decimals, limited to thousandths, using personal strategies.

A5C067BF9346484C92515509E383E792.description: Explain why keeping track of place-value positions is important when adding and subtracting decimals.

91727ECDD4F345C79C12139D29BAB3A4.description: Use estimation to correct errors of decimal point placements in sums and differences without using paper and pencil.

3435D19DCD654B3F94C806FCDC9B472E.description: Predict sums and differences of decimals using estimation strategies.

70CAC48C6CCE4C478C46224F14DF2A62.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of addition and subtraction of
decimals (limited to thousandths).

42EF260E43EE43A4A5ACC3DA8985931C.description: Compare and order a given set of decimals, including tenths, hundredths, and thousandths, using equivalent decimals.

EC92C8FCD787435AB2D26790111AE80B.description: Explain what is the same and what is different about 0.2, 0.20, and 0.200.

DD8BB0CBE84641E0878D3F43BFE8B638.description: Compare and order a given set of decimals including only thousandths using place value.

5F84C2BD3089483CA504DBA67126D042.description: Compare and order a given set of decimals including only hundredths using place value.

188AB2D347EA44F8A457D83688679F7D.description: Compare and order a given set of decimals including only tenths using place value.

0AC9CC464CFC4C93929FFECC5390FBFE.description: Compare and order a given set of decimals by placing them on a number line that contains the benchmarks 0.0, 0.5, and 1.0.

B35343B46263458680A4B505B5AD37DF.description:
Students will be expected to compare and order decimals (to thousandths) by using benchmarks,
place value, and equivalent decimals.

48D8E27856924B9CBDCBEAF1E4A11F10.description: Express a given pictorial or concrete representation as a fraction or decimal (e.g., 250 shaded squares on a thousandth grid can be expressed as 0.250 or 250 1000).

99BE1863870C490DBA72E1B0C60BF305.description: Represent the fractions 1 2 1 4 , 3 4 and as decimals using base-ten blocks, grids, and number lines.

529D8CD0B57A425587AE876DCEB7E205.description: Express, orally and symbolically, a given decimal in fraction form.

F1B5CF9D5B9C478CA1F456B2DC883B69.description: Read decimals as fractions (e.g., 0.45 is read as zero and forty-five hundredths).

F00C7A47EFBC407A8C60B4D624464039.description: Express, orally and symbolically, a given fraction with a denominator of 10, 100, or 1000 as a decimal.

AEC3EB9E70E6466FA2391CB65C9DBFBD.description:
Students will be expected to relate decimals to fractions and fractions to decimals (to
thousandths).

D171C1E578DB436D97DE83C7B86C3186.description: Explain the value of each digit in a given decimal.

1190192A5C064368A911E8A5BB395362.description: Express a given hundredth as an equivalent thousandth.

F99A318195024C2EB343D4BCC4A2A2A6.description: Express a given tenth as an equivalent hundredth and thousandth.

2F086426366E40178E9D12A5F90870F1.description: Represent an equivalent tenth, hundredth, or thousandth for a given decimal, using concrete or visual representations.

31DE482CF1CB4BB5B056DA57F084A2D7.description: Represent a given decimal using concrete materials or a pictorial representation.

9B40A708CE2D4E43B1B0C2B261113BDA.description: Write the decimal for a given concrete or pictorial representation of part of a set, part of a region, or of a unit of measure.

91654729E5C944D3BD2837A522261408.description:
Students will be expected to describe and represent decimals (tenths, hundredths, and
thousandths) concretely, pictorially, and symbolically.

20D47F91C7E5461999CAE1B9F5BBF3C6.description: Formulate and verify a personal strategy for developing a set of equivalent fractions.

0F8736404EC943CFAF20D38BF328A7D6.description: Position a given set of fractions with like and unlike denominators on a number line, and explain strategies used to determine the order.

EADFA6FE1D254566AB05B534519EA507.description: Compare and order two given fractions with unlike denominators by creating equivalent fractions.

47CC7FD0BFB346FAB004AA4D375CE33B.description: Identify equivalent fractions for a given fraction.

E5B7BE54580E416F9EAF550C86EDD244.description: Determine if two given fractions are equivalent, using concrete materials or pictorial representations.

8679EF310F1A49819061712C0E0D1AB2.description: Model and explain that equivalent fractions represent the same quantity.

7ACAD877F9804BD8A0964326C85909BD.description: Create a set of equivalent fractions, and explain, using concrete materials, why there are many equivalent fractions for any given fraction.

E2597F222AAF4A0A80980B55A1DB4DA3.description: Represent a given fraction of one whole, set, linear model, or region using concrete materials.

016943B93AE64DD5A79DBE8676FB990F.description: compare and order fractions with like and unlike denominators

BCE0B92880FD4459A23EA7AB1FFA66E5.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of fractions by using concrete,
pictorial, and symbolic representations to

9BD03059E79441EBAB24C4595FCABA76.description: Determine the quotient of two given numbers using a personal strategy and record the process symbolically.

705358415CC74AADB6EC2C9714FF53E9.description: Create and solve division story problems, and record the process symbolically.

F44B3417F983422FB525538EEA478556.description: Solve a given division problem in context, using personal strategies, and record the process.

D8232F6EE60F4E9383A2BB0C6C871A7B.description: Express remainders as decimals (e.g., measurement and money).

907BD614DE6B4CC391B1DEE5E1DB02BE.description: Express remainders as fractions (e.g., five apples shared by two people).

2C4537B6847A4933A7745B780611CA6C.description: Round the quotient up (e.g., the number of five-passenger cars required to transport 13 people).

8A819CE6F1F74DE8999624E0FA14F139.description: Ignore the remainder (e.g., making teams of four from 22 people [five teams, but two people are left over]).

3C728FD8A80D4686A64CF21B5E48936B.description: Explain that the interpretation of a remainder depends on the context.

E35C1BDCD0FE48739A9429FFE78A84E3.description:
Model the division of two given numbers, using concrete or visual representations, and
record the process symbolically.

9818B8D76D7C4E96882E8F5CEA5842B5.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate, with and without concrete materials, an understanding
of division (three-digit by one-digit), and interpret remainders to solve problems.

9E6940A50D1C44ADAFD22D5E1F4E9FF9.description: Determine the product of two given numbers using a personal strategy and record the process symbolically.

0A54620E22124816A5629CC382C556FA.description: Create and solve multiplication story problems, and record the process symbolically.

5925B3EC9E8A42F5914BEE4AF8245B70.description: Solve a given multiplication problem in context, using personal strategies, and record the process.

8FF50E1482FD4D57B7ACF370037F09A3.description: Describe a solution procedure for determining the product of two given two-digit factors, using a pictorial representation such as an area model.

6A31F7F467F2487C8529E7319146F6FC.description: Represent both two-digit factors in expanded notation to illustrate the distributive property; for example, to determine the partial products of 36 × 42, record (30 + 6) × (40 + 2) = 30 × 40 + 30 × 2 + 6 × 40 + 6 × 2 = 1200 + 60 + 240 + 12 = 1512

68557A3DA15F47CC9A85F3FA4E9BF311.description: Illustrate partial products in expanded notation for both factors (e.g., For 36 × 42, determine the partial products for (30 + 6) × (40 + 2).).

9E5894F9964F43ADB208A4DBD59D9E05.description: Model the multiplication of two two-digit factors, using concrete and visual representations of the area model, and record the process symbolically.

B86A5A5016FF412B8FC22777B063E915.description:
Students will be expected to demonstrate, with and without concrete materials, an understanding
of multiplication (two-digit by two-digit) to solve problems.

E0D18E3B9E26421C8BA73466FF44EF8E.description: Apply the distributive property to determine a given product that involves multiplying factors that are close to multiples of 10 (e.g., 98 × 7 = (100 × 7) – (2 × 7)).

18C69A79E0A4437DAECA0EA9966B0D4D.description: Apply halving and doubling when determining a given product (e.g., 32 × 5 is the same as 16 × 10).

08C829E17AC24DDBA17E87CDA47BB01B.description: Determine the products when one factor is a multiple of 10, 100, or 1000.

2AFB15892C6C46838656D82ACEB91C9E.description: Students will be expected to apply mental mathematics strategies for multiplication, including

6F252BC5D0294939A91771C51B87497E.description: Quickly recall multiplication facts up to 9 × 9 and related division facts.

A05903BC90044391AF05C046F5A7AC58.description: Explain why division by 0 is not possible or is undefined (e.g., 8 ÷ 0).

E330104817794774B35A7DB46D725801.description: Explain why multiplying by 0 produces a product of 0 (zero property of multiplication).

39AA60DB6A0841EC9872E69AF7BD44B8.description: Describe the mental mathematics strategy used to determine basic multiplication or division facts.

945559E03F3E40CF8BB2DB4807002E90.description:
Students will be expected to describe and apply mental mathematics strategies and number
properties to recall, with fluency, answers for basic multiplication facts to 81 and related division facts.

DF880E5B84E8405EB0F4DE02BE29302E.description: Select and explain an estimation strategy for a given problem.

556EF2FD2131412E8A96A883CB54476C.description: Estimate a sum, a difference, a product, or a quotient using an appropriate strategy.

84054627F6DB48AFA70B08D15FA20DA6.description: Determine the approximate solution to a given problem not requiring an exact answer.

BA3639B81A344DDC8B9B48770A12843C.description: Describe contexts in which overestimating is important.

32C3B3A9AC964DA58268FC268027EC6F.description: Provide a context for when estimation is used to make predictions, check the reasonableness of an answer, and determine approximate answers.

231F169D14DD47919EE4B1AAC89747B8.description:
Students will be expected to use estimation strategies, including front-end, front-end adjusted,
rounding, and compatible numbers in problem-solving contexts.

7F4F2DF1901D432C9D2272DE73910244.description: Read and write given numerals, 0 to 1 000 000, in words.

0452CB7248CF45C0B4B8B401D7510FC1.description: Represent a given number, 0 to 1 000 000, using expressions.

1EC4E0B38FE44F3FAD4F40612827F685.description: Represent a given number, 0 to 1 000 000, in a variety of ways, and explain how they are equivalent.

6A9A9BE405B04D889F679F3C479260D8.description: Represent a given numeral, 0 to 1 000 000, using a place-value chart.

3129A1491B434EE2AE0FF8D9B6A5AC49.description: Compare and order numbers to 1 000 000 in a variety of ways.

C96A4BD0D1C44D0CB9C5526A9979CBAD.description: Write the numeral represented by a given expanded notation.

6EBAA5B5818D46D0B62E387179FFBB79.description: Express a given numeral in expanded notation.

152209DB0DD44D6CA13BB944F967809E.description: Provide examples of large numbers used in print or electronic media.

9B3B5E29911442E6A9A3E6FB3529205C.description: Explain the meaning of each digit in a given numeral.

5710EDD3407E4A948BF6C677FCF8EF56.description: Describe the pattern of adjacent place positions moving from right to left.

260309BC13384ADBBD3D604BCEA0BE7A.description: Record numerals for numbers expressed orally, concretely, pictorially, or symbolically as expressions, using proper spacing without commas.

7E14676355424004BDEDDC35ECF58742.description: Read a given numeral without using the word “and.”

DD73B7B3D1274898B09A0C8E2E43BF4C.description: Students will be expected to represent and partition whole numbers to 1 000 000.
